title: 109_s1260
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005" requires consultation with state, local, and tribal governments. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2719) is amended to specify conditions for Indian tribes in Oklahoma without reservations to engage in gaming activities. The amendment to Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act specifies exceptions for Indian lands in Oklahoma without reservations to establish gaming establishments after consultation with relevant authorities within 60 miles. The amendment to Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act requires the concurrence of the Governor and legislative body of the State for gaming activities proposed within 60 miles of affected land. This does not apply to land where a gaming facility is already in operation. The land must be within the State where the Indian tribe is primarily located, as determined by the Secretary. The Indian tribe's primary geographic, social, and historical nexus to land is determined by the Secretary. This includes land owned by or held in trust for the tribe within designated geographical areas where financial assistance and social services are provided. The Indian tribe's primary geographic, social, and historical nexus to land is determined by the Secretary, including land on or near a reservation or within a designated geographical area where the majority of tribe members reside. This also includes land in states other than Oklahoma. The Indian tribe must conduct gaming activities on one contiguous parcel of Indian lands located within the boundaries of the last recognized reservation of the tribe in any state other than Oklahoma. SEC. 3. TRIBAL GAMING ORDINANCES. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2710) is amended to specify conditions for conducting class II gaming on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for the benefit of Indian tribes. Indian tribe authorized to conduct class II gaming activities on Indian lands under specified conditions. The text discusses the authorization for Indian tribes to conduct class III gaming activities on Indian lands under certain conditions, including lands taken into trust for the tribe's benefit. It also defines the term "State" as the Governor and legislative body of the State. SEC. 4. INVESTIGATION AND APPROVAL. The Chairman and Commission powers under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act are amended to include approving or disapproving the involvement of individuals with the highest financial interest in gaming activities. The Commission is required to identify these individuals and conduct background investigations. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to require background investigations by the Commission on individuals with significant financial interests in gaming activities, including tribal gaming commissioners and key employees. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to require ongoing background investigations by the Commission on key individuals in the gaming enterprise, with an increase in funding from $8,000,000 to $16,000,000. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to include new requirements for changing the use of Indian lands for gaming purposes, including submitting an environmental impact statement and obtaining consent from the Secretary. Existing compacts or agreements related to gaming regulation will not be affected by these changes.
